Subject: Official Response to Critical Factors Paper
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749; y=NGKCzJ7Fdqkc7RZMpbrLOffmQIqeyu7H-O8pFNExsC4L1NfOHcZ5
X-Yahoo-Profile: kenstanley01

Some of you may recall that our group was running studies in response to Th=
omas van den Berg and Shimon Whiteson's recent paper on Critical Factors in=
 the Performance of HyperNEAT.  A full tech report of our results is now av=
ailable at:
 
http://tr.eecs.ucf.edu/77/1/stanley_ucftr13-05.pdf
 
Abstract=
: http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/publications/2013/stanley-ucftr13-05
 
The aim of=
 this response is mainly to show that HyperNEAT is indeed able to solve tas=
ks that are interesting or that require adding hidden nodes, and that CPPNs=
 can encode fracture.  Two of the three tasks in the original paper are rei=
mplemented and solved effectively  in this paper, and source code is provid=
ed.  The paper also shows through detailed examples that HyperNEAT (and CPP=
Ns in general) can encode complex forms of fracture. 
 
While these results=
 may seem to contradict the original, I think the right interpretation is p=
erhaps that there are many factors that go into any experiment in this area=
, and differences in the population size, length of runs, system parameters=
, or experimental setup can all influence the results.  In this sense, Thom=
as and Shimon's original results are not necessarily contradictory to the f=
indings reported here, which simply show that it is possible to create cond=
itions that lead to solutions in these domains.  We hope in any case that t=
hese results provide some reassurance to those beginning to apply HyperNEAT=
 that there is no fundamental concern to be worried about.
 
That said, Tho=
mas and Shimon have done a service to point out that, especially under targ=
et-based conditions, fitness functions that might not seem initially too ch=
allenging can be surprisingly deceptive.   Our response accordingly also tr=
ies to highlight that it will be important in GDS to reduce our reliance on=
 reward functions based strictly and only on a target objective.  Many of t=
he concerns raised in their paper mainly apply under such strictly target-b=
ased conditions. 
 
We hope especially for new HyperNEAT users this respons=
e provides some encouragement and tips on how to get around potential obsta=
cles (like structural mutation rates being too low, population sizes too sm=
all, or runs too short). 
 
Finally I'd like to state publicly that Thomas =
and Shimon are both great colleagues who have made a very professional effo=
rt to accommodate our response and keep the lines of communication open bet=
ween our groups, all of which is healthy for the field and for science in g=
eneral.    
                                                               =
                                   
Best,
 
ken
